subject: Re: [junit] Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: ... I don t know if I misinterpret what You wrote but I feel I need to clairfy that tests with JUnit are written by the same person that implements them and it
messageBody:
> So I don't see how you can write a test class that has failing tests
> that move over to passing tests as you write the code, (as I see TDD
> asking for) when the thing you're testing doesn't exist yet.

I don't know if I misinterpret what You wrote but I feel I need to
clairfy that tests with JUnit are written by the same person that
implements them and it goes "test a little - code a little - refactor"
in very short iterations. Those types of tests are also called
developer-tests for that reason.

If you want to specify your system with tests "up front" sort of to
have a checklist "when that thing is green it is done, take the next
read thing and continue" I think automated acceptance testing with FIT
or similar is what you need. Those tools are complementary to
developer tests (it is not either or).

I got the impression that you thought that someone else (like a
tester) specifies what should be done as a test and then checks it in
and someone else (a developer) implements it. When doing TDD you can
never check in code that does not compile or fails any developer
tests. I got that impression reading between the lines in this
comment:

> But practically, I can't write such a test as a Java class in Eclipse
> without it failing to compile and thus breaking our automatic build
> procedures.

Compilation errors are also failures so as soon as something doesn't
compile you fix it but adding the code to fix the compilation problem.
Robert C Martin puts it like this:

"Over the years I have come to describe Test Driven Development in
terms of three simple rules. They are:

1. You are not allowed to write any production code unless it is to
make a failing unit test pass.
2. You are not allowed to write any more of a unit test than is
sufficient to fail; and compilation failures are failures.
3. You are not allowed to write any more production code than is
sufficient to pass the one failing unit test."
-- Robert C Martin

It is elaborated here:
http://butunclebob.com/ArticleS.UncleBob.TheThreeRulesOfTdd

Of course it is possible that I read too much between the lines.
/Joakim Ohlrogge
